title: Do you think that life is better for those who are selfish? - Quora

response.answer_text: One answer people love giving is that being selfish is good, everyone is actually selfish and does everything to get something in return. This statement is true and false. Both scenarios can be explained. But first let us study the life we have. whether we like it or not everything is cyclic. The water evaporates and collects into clouds and finally rains, giving back the water that evaporated. We see proof of cyclic behaviour everywhere. Things are born they live then perish and new life is born again. Whether its flowers, fruits, living creatures, day and night. What this shows is that if one becomes selfish then one is breaking the cycle and then harmony is broken. If you become a dead end like, you take things but never give back. You only care for your own comfort and pleasure and never bother about others. If this is the selfish which seems better then its not good and eventually will cause disruption and pain. Coming back to the first statement. A person can claim to be selfish and very happy. For instance a mother will do all for the kid because of the pleasure she gets to see the kid happy. It can be termed that she was being selfish. But this is positive selfish. When you give a lot and receive back it may be called selfish but there is a difference. Doing something with intent to get back can be termed selfish. But doing something selflessly and receiving back is positive selfish. The person would have been happy even if nothing came back. This is a high stage of being selfless and getting rewards. The good we do should be done with the intent that your action will positively alter the society around you. The long term ‘selfish’ intent is the good of all humanity. So be selfish but selflessly.

Selfish people think so, but in reality, nah selfish people think that having more means they’re better, but what does better have to do with being happy or being successful, being better means you rely more on what you have rather than what you want. To win in life is to keep living, doing what you wanna do, never grabbing useless things that do stuff that you can do and in more ways, life is more than technology and being successful, life is experiencing the highs and lows of what it gives you, you don’t need money to be happy. Society doesn’t decide whether you should be happy or sad, you make the decision never should someone say otherwise. :)

Life is the same for all humans, the only difference is how we perceive it. Circumstances may be better for those who are more selfish, but that’s only because others are unwilling to really do anything about their inconsiderate actions. “Life” might seem better to those who are selfish, but they’re just making themselves into the enemies of others. When the others recognize this, their lives will (should) change quickly. This doesn't mean to use violence, but to remember that your words are a weapon. Attack the ideals that cause them to behave the way that they behave, and change that horrible person into a budding human.

No, you ultimately reap what you sow in this world. Where it gets particularly worse is whenever you do something today that makes you feel immense sorrow years down the road. I've had multitudes of terrible things done to me, I hope someone's there for them when it finally sinks in or I hope that it never does for their sake.

Not always. Because there is only one of you, and lots of other people. Do you want to serve your person only, to the exclusion of everybody else, especially when everybody else is supposed to be a reflection of you? That seems like a pretty lopsided plan. It might work, but it seems unlikely. Why not do it the easy way and serve some other people as well?

Selfish as we know it universally tends to allude that we are unable to provide for others because we are only focused on providing for ourselves. I am certain that when we allow ourselves to be “selfish” we are able to take care of others because we are provided for. We are self-full and can share energy and time and love in a way that those who are not can’t. There is no winning in life. We all have our own unique paths and we all, at some point, leave our physical bodies. Some of us allow ourselves to become and grow through out our lives. The becoming and the growing is not winning, it is accelerating as a result of being untamed by fear.

Not always but man do some ungrateful people you help make you want to be that much more selfish and less helpful. That's for sure only you decide what best suites you and if being selfish will help you prosper more than being considerate and generous.

It depends. Are you selfish at the expense of others? There is an evolutionary and mathematical reason to be reasonably neutral in interactions with others. Here is a fun website that illustrates this: The Evolution of Trust To be selfish is good, to break law or harm others in doing so is bad for everyone involved.

No. We live in a society of good samaritans. If I thought my neighbour was being selfish. I would go over to his house and slap him, I would harass him and dedicate a portion of my life to setting things right. I mean don’t we all.

Ultimately-No. There is no contentment in selfish life style. We as humans find self contentment and fulfilment when we feel important and useful. Particularly to those close to us. Selfish people don't have that.
It's better to be selfish in the sense of being prudent and ambitious. It's not better in the sense of living by whims, or having a willingness to mistreat others.

No, but a healthy selfishness, coupled with a healthy level of altruism make you head far in life, if you act like that towards the right people = those who love and respect you. it’s better to have 2–3 good friends, VS having 100 fake/ bad ones.

You’re onto something bigger. Actually, everyone is selfish. The difference between selfish and “selfless” people is the amount of sympathy each shows for other people. Emotions are illogical and should not be used in decision making. So unless you benefit, you should not do anything for others.

Being called selfish doesn't feel like a compliment, but the trait can actually ... you show up as a healthy, grounded person in life,” says Bob Rosen, author ... “She is very self-aware and is always asking for feedback,” he says.
Yes and no. A balance of selfishness has to be found.
